title: 'Get out of the way' of Liddell closure: Grattan
text:
It said the state had too much "baseload" plant that needed to run constantly to remain profitable and that it instead needed more flexible plant, probably gas, that could run less frequently and respond to changing market conditions.

The institute said that about 2.3 gigawatts of new renewables had been committed in NSW since AGL first announced Liddell's closure, and acknowledged that more would probably be needed, as well as gas peaking generators such as those planned by AGL and EnergyAustralia.

Transmission upgrades

Transmission upgrades were also likely to help, so that "by the time Liddell is finally closed, electricity supplies in NSW will likely be about as reliable as they are today," Grattan said.

But many others are backing the federal and NSW governments' concerns, reasoning that the investment made so far to replace Liddell is dominated by intermittent renewables, with a 100 MW upgrade of the adjacent Bayswater coal generator the only other committed investment.

Jeff Jamieson, an energy and resources industry consultant and contributor to the Finkel Review, pointed out that the plant had generated 15 per cent of NSW's total generation this year, including 21 per cent in September, well beyond the contribution of renewable generation.

"Coal-fired capacity should not be removed from the NEM until we have operational confirmation and some decent experience to confirm renewables firming solutions are performing so as to be certain they can continuously contribute dispatchable power," Mr Jamieson said.

"So we need to extend the lives of our coal-fired stations as long as possible."
description: In findings that look certain to irk the federal and NSW governments, Grattan is calling for government to give investors a clear signal to replace Liddell.
